title: 109_hr6419
content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" is the short title of this Act. It includes definitions for various terms used in the legislation. The Act defines key terms such as "Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material," "design-basis threat," "formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material," and "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty." The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, signed in 1968 and enforced in 1970, defines a nuclear weapon as a device using atomic energy for weapon purposes. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure nuclear stockpiles and prevent nuclear smuggling have made progress, but further actions are necessary to minimize the risk of nuclear terrorism. The White House's National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave threat of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan warns that a nuclear terror attack would have devastating consequences on a global scale. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 emphasizes the importance of combating this threat through all available means. United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need for all countries to adopt and enforce laws prohibiting non-state actors from acquiring and using nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons for terrorist purposes. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency warns of the urgent race against time to prevent a terrorist attack using a nuclear weapon. Sense of Congress on the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The sense of Congress is that the threat of nuclear terror is the most horrific the US faces. A comprehensive approach is needed to reduce this danger, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear weapons worldwide, and prevent terrorist efforts to manufacture or transport nuclear explosives. The prevention of a nuclear terrorist attack on the US should be a top priority for the President. The President should prioritize preventing a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States and accelerate programs to combat nuclear terrorism, secure nuclear materials, and prevent nuclear smuggling. The International Atomic Energy Agency should be adequately funded to coordinate international efforts in protecting nuclear materials. Legislation by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a new section for a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Advisor's duties include advising the President on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating prevention policies, developing plans with measurable targets, addressing program gaps, and overseeing program implementation and diplomatic strategies. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is responsible for overseeing the development of program implementation strategies, budget requests, and new initiatives, as well as coordinating US efforts to implement policies. The Advisor may appoint necessary personnel to assist in performing duties. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a new paragraph in the Act, responsible for overseeing program strategies and coordinating US efforts. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a new paragraph in the Act. The President must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material, including a survey of global facilities and sites with nuclear weapons or related materials. The Senior Advisor to the President determines priority sites for security measures. The annual report to Congress includes a list of priority sites for securing nuclear weapons and materials, a plan for their removal or security, and an assessment of government efforts to secure such material globally. The annual report to Congress includes a plan with measurable milestones, metrics, and estimated costs for securing nuclear weapons and materials, along with a description of global efforts to secure such material. Additionally, it covers efforts to establish and implement security standards and related policies. The report may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States policy is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global nuclear security standard that effectively protects against threats from terrorists and criminals, considering equipment and human limitations, and is verifiable. In furtherance of the policy to ensure global nuclear security, the President will work with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade security measures in countries with nuclear weapons or special nuclear materials, providing financial and technical assistance as needed. The President will work with other countries to ensure effective nuclear security rules worldwide, including implementing a regulatory design-basis threat model to defeat threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008: $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
